item.title: Israel orders new evacuations as it prepares to expand Rafah operations
item.dc:creator: Richard Engel and Alexander Smith
item.description: The Israeli military issued an “urgent warning” to evacuate parts of Rafah, signaling an expansion of its military campaign in Gaza's southernmost city.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians transport their belongings on the back of a van as they flee Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip to a safer location on May 11, 2023, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the militant group Hamas. Israeli strikes hit Gaza on May 11 after renewed US criticism over its conduct of the war and a UN warning of "epic" disaster if an outright invasion of crowded Rafah city occurs.
media:content.media:description: Palestinians transport their belongings on the back of a van as they flee Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip to a safer location on May 11, 2023, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the militant group Hamas. Israeli strikes hit Gaza on May 11 after renewed US criticism over its conduct of the war and a UN warning of "epic" disaster if an outright invasion of crowded Rafah city occurs.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Palestinians displaced by the Israeli air and ground offensive on the Gaza Strip arrive at a makeshift tent camp west of Rafah on Friday.

media:content.media:text: Smoke rises above damaged buildings
media:content.media:description: Smoke rises above buildings during an early morning Israeli strike on Rafah Saturday.

item.title: In China, poker is out, while ‘throwing eggs’ is in
item.dc:creator: Cheng Cheng and Larissa Gao
item.description: As American investors pull funds out of China, local financiers are focusing on finding business domestically, and learning a Chinese card game that might help.

media:content.media:text: Guandan is a poker game originated in Huai 'an, where the game is played by four people in pairs.
media:content.media:description: Players competing in the final of a guandan competition in China’s Jiangsu province last year.

item.title: Switzerland’s Nemo becomes Eurovision's first nonbinary winner
item.description: Malmö, Sweden, plays host this year, as performers from 25 countries take the stage for the final.

media:content.media:text: Nemo from Switzerland celebrates with the trophy for winning Eurovision
media:content.media:description: Nemo from Switzerland celebrates with the trophy for winning the final of the Eurovision Song Contest in the Malmö Arena in Sweden on May 12, 2024.

item.title: Battles rage across Gaza as death toll tops 35,000 and tens of thousands evacuate Rafah
item.dc:creator: Hala Gorani and Mithil Aggarwal
item.description: Battles between Israeli forces and Hamas across Gaza after thousands people heeded evacuation orders to seek shelter elsewhere in the enclave.

media:content.media:text: Displaced Palestinians evacuate along a road of rubble
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians evacuate from the Tal al-Zaatar camp for Palestinian refugees in Gaza on May 11, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Smoke rises above damaged buildings
media:content.media:description: Smoke rises above buildings during an early morning Israeli strike on Rafah, Gaza, on Saturday.

media:content.media:text: Palestinian civilians flee Rafah in southern Gaza
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians transport their belongings on the back of a truck as they move to a safer area in Rafah, Gaza, on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: A Palestinian wounded in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip
media:content.media:description: A Palestinian wounded in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip is brought to a hospital in Rafah, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Many Iranian Jews in ‘Tehrangeles’ say their allegiance is to Israel, not Iran
item.dc:creator: Alicia Victoria Lozano
item.description: As pro-Palestinian protesters clash with counter-protesters at U.S. colleges, among the most vocal defenders of Israel are members of the Iranian-Jewish community.

media:content.media:text: Photo collage of Abby Yosian and a campus counter-protest at UCLA
media:content.media:description: Abby Yosian, right, made a new friend from Israel, Charlotte Korchak, left, at an outdoor Passover seder near the University of Southern California.

item.title: Professor seen on video verbally attacking woman in hijab will no longer teach at Arizona State
item.dc:creator: Dennis Romero and Erick Mendoza
item.description: An Arizona State University academic seen in viral video confronting a woman in a hijab during a pro-Israel protest near campus has been booted from the institution, ASU said this week.

media:content.media:text: ASU research scholar, Jonathan Yudelman.
media:content.media:description: ASU research scholar, Jonathan Yudelman.

item.title: Biden faces new Democratic divisions after Israel shift
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba and Emma Barnett and Alex Tabet and Alec Hernández and Sahil Kapur
item.description: President Joe Biden significantly shifted his policy toward Israel this week by threatening to withhold U.S. weapons if the Israeli government moves forward with a full-scale invasion of Rafah in the Gaza Strip, while also pledging “ironclad” support for the Jewish state in a speech condemning the rise of antisemitism.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden at a campaign event in Raleigh, N.C., on March 26.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: U.S. citizens are languishing in Chinese prisons with little hope of release
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Abigail Williams and Dan De Luce and Rae Wang
item.description: As Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited China this week, the most important issue for hundreds of families in the U.S. was when their loved ones imprisoned in the country are coming home.

media:content.media:text: Nelson Wells Jr of Bossier City, La., who is currently detained in China.
media:content.media:description: Nelson Wells Jr. has been imprisoned in China for almost a decade.

item.title: They were promised jobs in Russia. They ended up fighting in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Muheet Ul Islam
item.description: Families of Indian migrant workers forced to fight alongside the Russian army in Ukraine say they feel they have no choice but to travel there to help them.

media:content.media:text: Indians hired to fight Russia's Ukraine war - 28 Feb 2024
media:content.media:description: Relatives of Azad Yousuf Kumar at his home in the Pulwama district of Indian-administered Kashmir in February.

media:content.media:text: Indians hired to fight Russia's Ukraine war - 28 Feb 2024
media:content.media:description: Raja Begum, Kumar’s mother, displaying his photo as he wears a military uniform.

item.title: China's stressed and overworked youth skip the tea and reach for coffee
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Dawn Liu and Rae Wang
item.description: China has overtaken in the U.S. with the most branded coffee shops in the world as young people start drinking coffee to cope with a competitive job market and workplace.

media:content.media:text: A barista prepares drinks at a coffee shop in Beijing on March 6th, 2024.
media:content.media:description: A barista prepares drinks at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Li Yizhe turned to the energy boost of coffee to keep up with China's competitive work culture.
media:content.media:description: Li Yizhe turned to the energy boost of coffee to keep up with China's competitive work culture.

media:content.media:text: A patron works on a laptop at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: A patron works on a laptop at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Wang Zichen, a former cafe owner, at SIP coffee in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: Wang Zichen, a former cafe owner, at SIP coffee in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Wang Binqi at Mer coffee shop in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: Wang Binqi at Mer coffee shop in Beijing.

item.title: Switzerland’s Nemo crowned as Eurovision's first nonbinary winner
item.description: Switzerland's Nemo has claimed the 2024 Eurovision trophy, becoming the first nonbinary winner in the contest's history. They explained ahead of the final that their song “The Code” is about discovering their identity. Nemo dominated the international jury vote for a total of 591 points ahead of second-placed Croatia.

media:content.media:title: Switzerland’s Nemo crowned as Eurovision's first nonbinary winner
media:content.media:description: Switzerland's Nemo has claimed the 2024 Eurovision trophy, becoming the first nonbinary winner in the contest's history. They explained ahead of the final that their song “The Code” is about discovering their identity. Nemo dominated the international jury vote for a total of 591 points ahead of second-placed Croatia.

item.title: Israeli offensive in Rafah appears imminent as residents say there is nowhere safe to go
item.description: Israel expanded evacuation orders in Rafah as their offensive in southern Gaza appears imminent. Residents said there is nowhere safe to go, and President Biden said that the U.S. will withhold arms shipments if Israel invades Rafah. NBC News’ Hala Gorani reports.

media:content.media:title: Israeli offensive in Rafah appears imminent as residents say there is nowhere safe to go
media:content.media:description: Israel expanded evacuation orders in Rafah as their offensive in southern Gaza appears imminent. Residents said there is nowhere safe to go, and President Biden said that the U.S. will withhold arms shipments if Israel invades Rafah. NBC News’ Hala Gorani reports.

item.title: Pro-Palestinian protesters clash with police outside Eurovision venue
item.description: Police were seen forcibly removing pro-Palestinian demonstrators at a protest outside the Malmo Arena ahead of the Eurovision Song Contest final. Thousands gathered in the city earlier to protest against Israel’s participation in the competition.

media:content.media:title: Pro-Palestinian protesters clash with police outside Eurovision venue
media:content.media:description: Police were seen forcibly removing pro-Palestinian demonstrators at a protest outside the Malmo Arena ahead of the Eurovision Song Contest final. Thousands gathered in the city earlier to protest against Israel’s participation in the competition.

item.title: Baby left behind in Gaza now thriving under care of doctor-turned-mother
item.description: She was left behind four months ago at Gaza's Al Shifa Hospital as it struggled to keep babies alive in the neonatal unit. Now, an abandoned baby named Angel is doing well, thanks to a doctor who took her in. NBC News' Erin McLauglin has an exclusive update.

media:content.media:title: Baby left behind in Gaza now thriving under care of doctor-turned-mother
media:content.media:description: She was left behind four months ago at Gaza's Al Shifa Hospital as it struggled to keep babies alive in the neonatal unit. Now, an abandoned baby named Angel is doing well, thanks to a doctor who took her in. NBC News' Erin McLauglin has an exclusive update.

item.title: Magnitude-6.4 earthquake strike rattles Mexico-Guatemala border
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: TAPACHULA, Mexico — A strong earthquake shook the border of Mexico and Guatemala early Sunday, driving frightened residents into the streets.

media:content.media:text: Migrants cross through the Mexico-Guatemala border
media:content.media:description: Migrants arrive to El Ceibo, Guatemala through the Mexico-Guatemala border on Aug. 19, 2021.

item.title: Canadian police announce the arrest of a fourth Indian suspect in the killing of a Sikh activist
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A fourth Indian national living in Canada has been charged in the slaying of a Sikh separatist leader last June that became the center of a diplomatic spat with India.

media:content.media:text: Sikh community members hold Canadian flags and signs
media:content.media:description: Members of British Columbia's Sikh community gather in front of the courthouse in Surrey, British Columbia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Spain watches closely as Catalans take separatist movement to the ballot
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Catalonia is holding a regional election on Sunday whose outcome will reverberate in Spain’s national politics.

media:content.media:text: Two voters submit their ballots in a ballot box
media:content.media:description: Voters submit their ballots at the Universitat de Barcelona on Sunday.

item.title: Thousands forced to evacuate as wildfire sweeps through Canada’s British Columbia
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Canadian authorities are urging residents in northeastern British Columbia to leave after thousands have already been evacuated due to a fast-growing wildfire.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: The Canadian city of Edmonton was put under an air quality advisory as high winds pushed smoke from the blaze in British Columbia into neighboring Alberta.

item.title: Auroras illuminate night skies around the world, expected to possibly continue through Monday
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Cohen and Jean Lee and Anisha Banerjee and Denise Chow and Evan Bush and Dennis Romero
item.description: Night skies were lit up by the northern lights Friday in locations the auroras don't normally shine as a severe solar storm supercharged the phenomenon.

media:content.media:text: Aurora borealis northern lights
media:content.media:description: Aurora borealis near Ranfurly in Central Otago, New Zealand, on May 10, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Aurora borealis northern lights
media:content.media:description: In Tyrol, Austria, the aurora looked bright pink Friday.

media:content.media:text: Aurora borealis northern lights
media:content.media:description: It could also be seen in the Penge neighborhood of London on Friday.

media:content.media:text: northern lights aurora borealis
media:content.media:description: The northern lights were visible in Pöstlingberg, Austria, on Friday.

media:content.media:text: aurora borealis northern lights alabama
media:content.media:description: There was a possibility the aurora borealis could be seen as far south as Alabama on Friday, and sure enough, forecasters in Calera got a glimpse of the phenomenon.

item.title: Mexico heat wave melts temperature records in 10 cities, including Mexico City
item.dc:creator: Reuters and Tangni Noriega
item.description: Ten cities in Mexico have registered record-high temperatures, including the capital, authorities said on Friday, amid a searing heat wave that has prompted blackouts nationwide and pushed the power grid to the brink.

media:content.media:text: People protect themselves from the sun.
media:content.media:description: People protect themselves from the sun in Guadalajara, Mexico, on May 9 during a heat wave hitting the country.

media:content.media:text: A man carries a jerrycan of water.
media:content.media:description: A man carries a jug of water in Guadalajara, Mexico, on May 9.

media:content.media:text: People frolic at the water fountain .
media:content.media:description: The Monument to the Revolution, amid high temperatures in Mexico City, on April 16.

item.title: Fighting rages near Ukrainian city of Kharkiv as Russia reports deaths in border regions
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Fierce fighting was raging on Saturday for control of several Ukrainian villages near close to the country's eastern border with Russia.

media:content.media:text: Aftermath of the explosion of a Russian missile in Kharkiv
media:content.media:description: Emergency responders at the site of a Russian missile attack in Kharkiv, Ukraine on May 10, 2024.

item.title: Hundreds killed by flash floods in northern Afghanistan, U.N. says
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Flash floods from unusually heavy seasonal rains in Afghanistan have killed more than 300 people and destroyed over 1,000 houses, the U.N. food agency said.

media:content.media:text: Afghan men clear debris and mud from a damaged house following a flash flood after a heavy rainfall in Laqiha village of Baghlan-i-Markazi district in Baghlan province on May 11, 2024. At least 62 people, mainly women and children, were killed on May 10 in flash flooding that ripped through Afghanistan's Baghlan province, in the north of the country, a local official told AFP.
media:content.media:description: Men clear debris and mud from a damaged house following a flash flood after a heavy rainfall in the village of Laqiha on Saturday.

item.title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un supervises latest test of new rocket launcher
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised another test firing of a new multiple rocket launch system state media said.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: In this photo provided by the North Korean government, Kim Jong Un (center) supervises a test firing of a new multiple rocket launch system.

item.title: The lights are going out for Hong Kong’s iconic neon signs
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Samra Zulfaqar and Alice Kong
item.description: Hong Kong’s famous neon signs are becoming harder and harder to find.

media:content.media:text: Hongkong, Hong Kong - November, 2019: Neon lights and shop signs in Hong Kong streets at night
media:content.media:description: Neon lights and shop signs in Hong Kong in 2019.

media:content.media:text: Hong Kong Neon
media:content.media:description: Construction workers removing a neon sign from a restaurant in Hong Kong last year.

media:content.media:text: Hong Kong Neon Signs
media:content.media:description: A neon sign being removed from a pawn shop in Hong Kong last year.

media:content.media:text: Neon Signs Removed Hong Kong
media:content.media:description: Dozens of removed neon signboards are stored in rural Hong Kong by Tetra Neon Exchange.

media:content.media:text: Neon Signs Disappearing Hong Kong
media:content.media:description: Neon sign maker Wu Chi-kai in Hong Kong in 2018.
